results.title: Multicultural education: a teaching style
results.creator_credit: Media Five Film, David Arnold, Dennis Hicks and Wayne Threm
results.brief_description: Looks at the change from the traditional “melting pot” theory to an appreciation of cultural pluralism. Several classroom approaches are demonstrated which encourage ethnic groups to maintain their identity and pride and at the same time learn mutual respect. Suitable for teacher/tertiary level.

results.title: Multicultural Australia
results.brief_description: Richard Morecroft looks at popular images of Australia, “Australianness” and Australian culture, in an attempt to define what being an Australian means. Useful in the studies of immigration, problems of refugees, Australian history and Australian life.

results.title: Muloorina
results.creator_credit: Film Producers Guild, Cinesound, Ronald H. Riley and David Cobham
results.brief_description: In 1962 Donald Campbell made his second attempt to break the worl land speed record on the salt flats of Lake Eyre, 35 miles north-east of Muloorina, a homestead 450 miles north of Adelaide, and settled by Elliot Price and his family in 1939; their struggle to establish a sheep station on the drought ridden land and the effect Campbell’s attempt had on the homestead.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Producers Guild, Cinesound, Ronald H. Riley and David Cobham

results.title: Mullet [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Premium Movie Partnership, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Vincent Sheehan and David Caesar
results.brief_description: Eddie Maloney (Ben Mendelsohn) whose nickname is ‘Mullet’ (aptly named after a fish that no-one likes eating), unexpectedly returns home to Coollawarra after a three year absence. Surprisingly, not many people are too happy to see him back in town, particularly his estranged family who greet his arrival with some apprehension. None more so than his law enforcing brother Pete (Andrew Gilbert) who is now married to Eddie’s childhood sweetheart, Tully (Susie Porter). David Caesar’s understated screenplay interweaves pointed metaphor to explore the ties that bind and separate family. The story unfolds through a series of well observed and familiar characterizations, while unashamedly wearing it’s Australianness on it’s sleeve. The vibrant cinematography by Robert Humphreys gives the story a sense of magic realism, while the characters quiet musical interludes are surprisingly and nicely understated. Cast includes Belinda McClory, Kris McQuade, Tony Barry, Peta Brady and Wayne Blair.

results.title: Mull
results.creator_credit: Ukiyo Films, D. Howard Grigsby and Don McLennan
results.brief_description: Based on the popular novel “Mullaway” by Bron Nicholls, “Mull” is the story of a 16 year old girl’s struggle to turn 17, movingly portrayed by Nadine Garner in an AFI Award winning performance. Mull’s brother is a junkie, her father’s a religious fanatic and her mum’s about to die. So Mull does what she has to do and gives up school to keep the family together any way she can. Other notable performances are from Bill Hunter, Sue Jones and Mary Coustas.

results.title: Mulholland Drive
results.creator_credit: Asymmetrical Productions, Imagine Television, Studio Canal+, Les Films Alain Sarde, Picture Factory, Mary Sweeney, Alain Sarde, Neal Edelstein, Michael Polaire, Tony Krantz and David Lynch
results.brief_description: Betty Elms (Naomi Watts) has arrived in Hollywood dreaming of being a star. But when she goes to stay at her Aunt’s apartment she finds it occupied by the lovely Rita (Laura Elena Harring) who has lost her memory and is terrified for her life. From the most basic of plots and narrative cliche, David Lynch furnishes a deeply troubling and deeply erotic investigation of Hollywood, a vision which has the logic and texture of a hallucinatory dream. Both Betty and Rita, and their alter egos, Diane and Camilla, embody competing versions of celebrity and fame: movies as success and Hollywood as destruction. But attempting to explain “Mulholland Drive” in linear terms is self-defeating. A continuation of Lynch’s ground-breaking work in “Blue Velvet”, “Twin Peaks” and “Lost Highway”, the surreal sequences in the film are never excessively melodramatic or ridiculous; they are often moving and chilling. Lynch creates a singularly impressive mise-en-scene of the unconscious which places him in the forefront of contemporary cinema. “Mulholland Drive” began as a pilot for a TV series. When the producers were alarmed by Lynch’s work, they cancelled the series. Fortunately, Lynch was able to eventually secure funding from European production sources. But this difficult genesis and production history has been written into the final film itself, where the Machiavellian game which is filmmaking in Hollywood is re-cast in stark visual metaphors of good and of evil. In Lynch’s universe, the Devil is a cowboy.

results.title: Mulga Bill's Bicycle Band
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Bob Connolly
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Mulga Bill’s Bicycle Band, a group of musicians from Melbourne, play adaptations of English and Irish folk music. This episode of A Big Country follows the band as they rescue their music from the abstractions of television studios and return it to the living ambience of country halls and hotels.

results.title: Mules and tail operation
results.creator_credit: Australian Wool Corporation and Tom Price
results.brief_description: The modified mules operation and the tail-strip operation now being increasingly practised by wool-growers in Australia is demonstrated in this informative film. The saving in time, money and labour effected by wool-growers who carry out these operations correctly is emphasised.
